title: When writing and formatting a novel, what are the rules for scene breaks? - Quora

response.answer_text: Scene breaks are usually for when there’s some break in continuity, either in place or time. Sometimes you can continue a scene by saying something like “a few minutes later,” if you wish to continue on without a break. As to how to show a scene break, the “* * *” centered on the line seems to be the usual, but I’d check with your publisher to make sure. They may have a different standard they want you adhere to. Dependent upon the type of novel, they may decide on some special character based on genre or even your story. While you’re writing, make it something simple and unique, like the above, so that a quick find-n-replace will take care of it.

From my experience, I’d say it depends on the publisher. Many of them have their own rules about how to mark a scene break. If I don’t know the particular standard, I skip a line and put a hashtag mark centered on the blank line. If I get far enough with the submission that it matters whether the publisher wants something different, the editor will tell me what to change.
